courses.subject: EASC
courses.title: Solid and Fluid Mechanics
courses.description: This course presents the fundamentals of continuum mechanics illustrated with earth system science applications. Background materials on matrices, vectors and differential operators are first reviewed. The following topics will be covered: tensors and their properties; stress and strain; constitutive equations for Hookean elastic solid and Newtonian viscous fluid; mechanical properties and rheology of geomaterials; Eulerian and Lagrangian kinematics; momentum equations; vorticity and divergence; applications in geomechanics, seismology, atmospheric dynamics, and oceanography.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Atmospheric Sciences
Not for students who have taken ESSC3010 or ESSC4010
courses.learning_outcomes: Students will acquire systematic training in continuum mechanics, a body of knowledge in mathematics and physics which is of critical importance in a diversity of earth system science applications, including geomechanics, seismology, atmospheric dynamics, and oceanography. The mathematical concepts are illustrated with geophysical examples. Students will be well equipped with useful background to pursue more advanced courses on physical aspects of earth system science.
courses.course_syllabus:
Topics

Vectors. Cartesian coordinates. Vector algebra.

Determinants. Change of orthonormal basis.

Tensors. Principal values and principal directions

Traction and stress tensor. Principal stresses.

Mohr’s circle.

Current and reference configurations. Strain tensor.

Infinitesimal strain tensor. Rigid body rotation.

Transformation of integrals. Velocity gradient, strain rate and vorticity.

Conservation of mass. Conservation of momentum. Conservation of energy. Ideal constitutive relations: inviscid fluid. Bernoulli’s equation. Potential flow. Ideal constitutive relations: viscous fluid. Steady and non-steady flow.

Ideal constitutive relations: linear solid.

Elastic waves and elasostatics.

courses.subject: EASC
courses.title: Soil Mechanics and Its Applications
courses.description: A survey of basic concepts of soil mechanics: Classification and physical properties of soil; stress and strain; pore pressure, seepage theory and effective stress; elastic solutions; shear strength and Mohr-Coulomb theory; failure mode and criteria; soil consolidation; lateral earth pressure; slope stability; bearing capacity and foundation designs; pile analyses and designs; soil improvement and soil nailing. Geotechnical applications: shallow and deep foundations; retaining structures; slope instability.

courses.learning_outcomes:
1. An understanding of the basics of poromechanics: stress and strain, pore pressure and effective stress, shear strength and failure criteria.
2. Knowledge of the classification and physical properties of soil.
3. A basic understanding of the mechanics of soil, soil consolidation and shear failure.
4. An appreciation of the application of soil mechanics to geotechnical designs and engineering.

* Seepage and effective stress, Pore pressure.
* Stress and strain. Shear strength.
* Soil consolidation. Geotechnical applications: shallow and deep foundations; retaining structures; slope instability.
* Laboratory measurement of soil deformation and strength.

courses.description: This course introduces concepts, principles, and applications of geophysical methods in environmental and engineering studies. It offers an overall survey of various geophysical methods for exploring the shallow subsurface. It provides the technical foundation needed to understand the use and limitations of gravity, seismic, ground penetrating radar, and electromagnetic methods. Demonstration of commonly used methods will be provided in the field along with tutorials of preliminary data analysis techniques. Technical papers published in leading applied geophysics journals will be discussed in reading groups.

- Students will gain a solid understanding of physical properties of soil and rocks determining geophysical properties
- Students will design and conduct geophysics field surveys, process, analyze, and interpret survey data using computer software
- Students will understand the advantages and limitations of geophysical methods when applied to environmental and engineering studies
- Students will critically understand and judge technical papers published in leading applied geophysics journals

* *Week 9** Lab: GPR instrument, common offset survey

* *Week 10** Lab: GPR: common-mid point survey, Processing GPR CMP data

courses.subject: EASC
courses.title: Petrology
courses.description: Petrology is an essential subfield of Earth System Science because the rock record is the foundation for interpreting Earth history and internal processes. Petrologic concepts help us understand the Earth system, with connections to related fields such as geochemistry, geophysics, mineralogy, structural geology and geodynamics. This course broadly surveys the formation, distribution, chemical composition, mineral associations, and internal texture and structures in rocks of the earth’s crust and upper mantle, and establishes it relation to global tectonic environments. Class lectures are supplemented by lab exercise, demonstrations and tutorials (e.g. study of rock hand specimens, understand phase rule, use of optical microscope etc.).
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Atmospheric Sciences
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are expected to gain the following abilities:
1. Gain the skills to identify different rock types (igneous and metamorphic basically).
2. Good knowledge of typical mineral assemblages of different rocks.
3. Use optical polarizing microscope to distinguish: (1) different minerals based on their optical properties, (2) typical igneous and metamorphic micro-textures and structures, (3) featured mineral assemblages corresponding to different P-T conditions.
4. Understand phase equilibrium and phase rule and their applications in understanding the rock forming process.
5. Understand different metamorphic facies and their significance of variable tectonic settings.
6. Use petrologic concepts and theories to address topics of societal interests, including natural hazards, natural resources, and human health issues.

The students will develop: 1) the ability to evaluate an issue critically based on evidence and scientific principle, 2) to acquire knowledge effectively by self-study and using information technology, and to work independently, 3) to work effectively in a team, and 4) to present information in a clear, concise and logical manner. The students also can acquire a responsible attitude in study and work, and have motivation for life-long learning.
courses.course_syllabus:
* Introduction and practice of Electronic Microscope for Petrologic Study
* Phase Rule
* Igneous Petrology
* Sedimentary Petrology
* Metamorphic Petrology

courses.subject: EASC
courses.title: Geomorphology
courses.description:
This course is an important part of the core Earth System Sciences Curriculum. It introduces the main concepts in geomorphology with emphasis on understanding the coupling of environments, processes and materials that leads to landform development. Understanding the underlying geological principles of rocks, minerals, structural deformation and geological time are important background knowledge to be enhanced by the study of geomorphology.
It discusses the qualitative and quantitative techniques for investigation and research in the field, laboratory, and computer modeling.
The application of geomorphology for public safety, engineering problems and development of sustainable solutions will be emphasized. Examples from theory and practice of geomorphology in Hong Kong will be introduced. Practical understanding and skills will be gained from lab exercises and field trips in Hong Kong.
Students are suggested to be equipped with basic knowledge of rocks and minerals, structural geology and geological time scale.

courses.subject: EASC
courses.title: Seismology
courses.description: This course focuses on the concepts and theory of elastic wave propagation and physics of earthquake. The topics covered include the Earth’s internal structure, material elasticity, travel time tomography, seismic ray theory, ray tracing, and earthquake source parameter. Methods and field practice of seismological survey and programming methods of data processing will also be introduced.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Atmospheric Sciences
courses.learning_outcomes: At the completion of this course, the students will be able to know about Earth’s inner structure, understand principles of elastic wave propagation and earthquake physics, seismic imaging, as well as seismic exploration. The students will also be trained with extensive computing exercises. The students will develop: 1) the ability to evaluate an issue critically based on evidence and scientific principle, 2) to acquire knowledge effectively by self-study and using information technology, and to work independently, 3) to work effectively in a team, and 4) to present information in a clear, concise and logical manner. The students also can acquire a responsible attitude in study and work, and have motivation for life-long learning.

- Overview of seismology
- Scalar wave equation and solutions
- Wave reflection and transmission; propagating and standing waves
• Stress and Strain

- Eigenvalue and eigenvectors
- Equation of motion
- Strain and rotation
- Elasticity and constitutive law
• Wave propagation
- Plane waves
- Geometrical spreading
- Wave propagation in layered medium
- Body waves
- Post-critical reflection and surface waves
- Rayleigh and Love waves
• Earthquake source kinematics
- Moment tensor solution
- Isotropic and CLVD components
- Stress drop
• Earthquake rupture dynamics
- Friction law
- Coseismic process and earthquake cycles

courses.subject: EASC
courses.title: Volcanoes
courses.description: On any given day, ~20 subaerial volcanoes worldwide are erupting. Even more submarine volcanoes are probably erupting without being detected. Volcanic eruptions can have devastating economic and social consequences, but are also the fundamental force that builds the majority of our planet’s surface. Volcanic eruptions and emissions can also affect atmospheric and climate conditions. This course will explore the various techniques used to study volcanoes’ underlying structure as well as their precursory and eruptive activity.

courses.learning_outcomes: At the completion of this course, the students will understand fundamental concepts related to volcanic systems as well as the various techniques used to monitor and study volcanoes. The students will also be trained to read scientific literature, learn new knowledge from them, and synthesize with existing knowledge. Finally, students will learn how to present scientific information in a clear, succinct, and logical manner in both oral and written form as well as in scientific discourse/debate.

* Volcanic hazards and risks
* Environmental impacts

* Submarine volcanism

courses.subject: EASC
courses.title: Marine Geology and Geophysics
courses.description: This course focuses on the concepts and theory of marine geology and geophysics. Marine geology is distinct from that of continent and is the important foundation to launch Plate Tectonics, the modern unified theory of the Earth. In this course, major components of marine geological settings such as mid-ocean ridges, transform faults, subduction zones, oceanic lithosphere, and etc. will be introduced and discussed in details. Methods of geophysical survey will also be introduced. Field experiments of scientific instruments such as Ocean Bottom Seismometers, marine magnetometer and gravimeter will be conducted. A geological field trip will also be included. This course will be jointly offered with Ocean College, Zhejiang University, as an initiative to develop ocean sciences at CUHK.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Atmospheric Sciences
courses.learning_outcomes: At the completion of this course, the students will be able to know about Earth’s inner structure, understand principles of marine geology, marine geophysical methods, as well as theory and application of scientific geophysical instruments. The students will also be trained with extensive computing exercises. The students will develop: 1) the ability to evaluate an issue critically based on evidence and scientific principle, 2) to acquire knowledge effectively by self-study and using information technology, and to work independently, 3) to work effectively in a team, and 4) to present information in a clear, concise and logical manner. The students also can acquire a responsible attitude in study and work, and have motivation for life-long learning.

courses.description: What is the mechanism of plate tectonics and a variety of geological phenomena, such as seafloor spreading, mountain building, volcanoes, earthquakes, faulting? Geodynamics is going to answer those questions through observations and models of the large-scale behaviors of the solid Earth. The goal of the course is to develop a thorough understanding of physical processes, such as lithospheric deformation, heat transfer, and mantle flow. Lectures, paper discussions, and tutorials will help you to understand the principle of geodynamics, learn how to develop simple but useful models, and explain how the Earth evolves.

4. Acquire the ability to read and summarize literatures effectively and efficiently.
5. Develop critical thinking on the previous studies.

courses.subject: EASC
courses.title: Land-Atmosphere Interactions and Boundary-Layer Meteorology
courses.description: This course introduces the physical, chemical and biological processes governing the exchange of energy, momentum, water and other chemical materials between the atmosphere and land surface, including a formal introduction into boundary-layer meteorology. Topics covered include the basic equations and concepts of heat, momentum and mass conservation and transfer at the land-atmosphere interface; soil physics and hydrometeorology; temperature, humidity and wind distribution in the atmospheric boundary layer; theories and observations of turbulence; stability and boundary-layer dynamics; biometeorology and ecophysiology of land plants; canopy and ecosystem exchange; and land use change and urbanization. Applications to weather phenomena, air pollution, forestry, agriculture and ecosystem management will be emphasized throughout.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Atmospheric Sciences
courses.learning_outcomes: At the completion of this course, the students will be able to 1) Gain knowledge of physical and chemical processes of land-atmosphere interactions and boundary layer dynamics; and 2) Develop the skill and ability to understand climate variability related to land-atmosphere interactions. (Course Outcomes as related to Programme Learning Outcomes) -- The students will develop: 1) the ability to evaluate an issue critically based on evidence and scientific principle, 2) to acquire knowledge effectively by self-study and using information technology, and to work independently, 3) to work effectively in a team, and 4) to present information in a clear, concise and logical manner. The students also can acquire a responsible attitude in study and work, and have motivation for life-long learning.

courses.description: This course introduces tropical atmospheric circulation and related air-sea coupling at a variety of spatial and temporal scales. The topics covered include the role of the tropics in the global energy and momentum balance, ITCZ, subtropical high, upper-level anticyclones, tropical ocean circulation, tropical weather, climate and atmosphere-ocean interaction phenomena including meso-scale convective systems, tropical waves, the Hadley and the Walker circulation, El Nino-Southern Oscillation, tropical cyclones, Madden Julian Oscillation, and monsoons.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Atmospheric Sciences
courses.learning_outcomes: At the completion of this course, the students will be able to 1) Gain the knowledge of various tropical atmospheric motions, 2) Understand physical processes in the tropical atmosphere; and 3) Apply knowledge to understand tropical climate variability. The students will develop: 1) the ability to evaluate an issue critically based on evidence and scientific principle, 2) to acquire knowledge effectively by self-study and using information technology, and to work independently, 3) to work effectively in a team, and 4) to present information in a clear, concise and logical manner. The students also can acquire a responsible attitude in study and work, and have motivation for life-long learning.
courses.course_syllabus:
* Radiativeand convection: Radiative Processes in the Tropics, Surface Energy Balance, Top of the Atmosphere Net Radiation Fluxes, Dry and Moist Stability, Moist Convection
* General circulation in the tropics: Observed zonally averaged Tropical circulation, Theory of the Hadley Cell, Zonally asymmetric circulation features, seasonal variations, diurnal cycle, Observed aspects of the Intertropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ), ITCZ theory, Gill model, Heat lows, Tropical ocean circulation, ocean waves.
* Monsoons: Deﬁnition, Differential Heating and the Monsoon, Key Elements of the Asian Summer and Winter Monsoon, Onset and Withdrawal, Breaks in the Indian Monsoon
* El Nino and Southern Oscillation (ENSO): Observational aspect, air-sea interaction, Bjerknes feedback, teleconnection, ENSO modeling, Indian Ocean Dipole
* Madden Julian Oscillation (MJO): Observational aspect, Theory of MJO, Westerly wind bursts, Connection with ENSO
* Tropical Waves and Tropical Depressions (TD): Matsuno wave theory, convective coupled equatorial waves, easterly waves and TD-type disturbances, relationship with Tropical Cyclones (TC) genesis
* TC: Structure, Genesis, dynamics of TC movement, and intensiﬁcation, modeling and forecasting
* Tropical Squall Lines and Mesoscale Convective Systems (MCS): Observations of MCS and squall lines, dynamical aspects, Organization of Convection

courses.description: Human modifications to the surface of the Earth during urbanisation change most of the elements of climate and weather in the urban atmosphere. This course introduces the fundamentals of urban climatology and the processes caused by the changes in the surface environment, particularly focusing on how urban structures interact with the atmospheric environment. Numerical modelling and field techniques are introduced to understand the underlying processes resulting urban climatic phenomena. It also examines the implications on human comfort and climate-sensitive urban planning and design, as well as the relationship between cities and climate change.

courses.description: This course presents an introduction to the science of clouds. We begin with a descriptive cloud classification to introduce the different types of clouds in the Earth’s atmosphere. The roles of aerosols in cloud are also discussed. This is followed by cloud microphysics, describing the basic microphysical processes regarding formation, growth, shrinkage, breakup and fallout of cloud and precipitation particles. Next, different structures of precipitation and radar cloud sensing are presented. This will then be linked to cloud dynamics, associated with the fluid motions of the atmosphere.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Atmospheric Sciences
courses.learning_outcomes: Students shall learn about a wide variety of physics and dynamics that control the occurrence, characteristics, and behavior of clouds. They shall understand the processes determining all the types of clouds in our atmosphere, over a wide range of spatial scales from microns to thousands of kilometers. They shall appreciate the importance of cloud to Earth’s climate. There are also be opportunities (e.g. outdoor cloud observation, cloud dynamics practicals both computationally and experimentally) where student can practice working effectively in a team, and present information in a clear, concise and logical manner.

courses.subject: EASC
courses.title: Practical Meteorology
courses.description: Practical Meteorology is designed to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of various aspects of meteorology and their practical applications. The course will cover synoptic and mesoscale meteorology, satellite and radar meteorology, radiative transfer, lidar meteorology, aviation meteorology, and atmospheric instrumentation. Through a combination of lectures and case studies using instrument data, students will gain hands-on experience in analyzing and interpreting meteorological data.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Atmospheric Sciences
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Analyze the concepts of synoptic and mesoscale meteorology and their impact on weather patterns and atmospheric processes.
2. Evaluate the principles and applications of satellite and radar meteorology in predicting weather conditions, detecting severe weather events, and investigating climate patterns.
3. Assess the fundamental principles of radiative transfer and its significance in maintaining energy balance, understanding climate change, and utilizing remote sensing techniques.
4. Examine the principles of lidar meteorology and its practical applications in profiling the atmosphere, studying aerosols, and analyzing the boundary layer.
5. Utilize atmospheric instrumentation data to conduct case studies, perform data analysis, and interpret findings to enhance understanding of meteorological phenomena.
6. Apply critical thinking and problem-solving skills to real-world scenarios by integrating meteorological concepts and theories into practical situations.
7. Evaluate the latest developments in practical meteorology from the literature to create individual presentations.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction to synoptic and mesoscale meteorology:

1. Weather systems and their characteristics
2. Analysis and interpretation of weather maps
3. Atmospheric circulation patterns
4. Frontal systems and their impacts

2. Satellite and radar meteorology:

1. Satellite remote sensing principles and techniques

2. Interpretation of satellite imagery for weather analysis

3. Radar systems and their applications in severe weather detection

4. Doppler radar and its role in analysing storm dynamics

3. Radiative transfer:

1. Solar radiation and its interaction with the atmosphere

2. Greenhouse effect and climate change

3. Remote sensing applications of radiative transfer

4. Lidar meteorology:

1. Principles of lidar remote sensing

2. Lidar applications in atmospheric profiling

3. Aerosol studies using lidar

4. Boundary layer analysis with lidar

5. Aviation meteorology:

1. Meteorological factors affecting aviation operations

2. Weather hazards and their impact on flight safety

3. Aviation weather forecasting techniques

4. Application of meteorological information in flight planning and decision-making

6. Atmospheric instrumentation:

1. Introduction to meteorological instruments

2. Principles of measurement and calibration

3. Analysis and interpretation of instrument data for case studies

courses.title: Statistical Methods and Data Analysis for Earth and Atmospheric Sciences
courses.description:
This course covers the theoretical basis and practical applications of data analysis relevant for earth system science. This course aims to introduce students to Earth and environmental data manipulation, from sampling, reading and writing, to statistical analysis and parameter estimation, to time series analysis, to plotting and visualization. Topics include: digital signal processing, sampling techniques; probability distributions; hypothesis testing; correlation analysis; linear and nonlinear regression; statistical forecasting, harmonic analysis and spectral analysis; principle component analysis; and geostatistics. Tutorials will be based on real geophysical examples including remote sensing and in situ observations, as well as model data.

Previous elementary coding experience in Python 3 is recommended.

Students will acquire knowledge on techniques for data processing, including visualization methods and statistical analysis, and on the applications of these data and tools to geophysical and environmental problems. The students will develop: 1) the ability to evaluate an issue critically based on evidence and scientific principles, 2) to acquire knowledge effectively by self-study and using information technology, and to work independently, 3) to work effectively in a team, and 4) to present information in a clear, concise and logical manner. The students can also acquire a responsible attitude in study and work, and have motivation for life-long learning.

courses.description: This course covers the principles of numerical methods and modeling relevant for earth and atmospheric sciences applications. Topics include: optimization; interpolation; finite differencing; numerical solutions to ordinary and partial differential equations; programming numerical models; filtered models; boundary conditions; subgrid-scale processes; data assimilation; applications in earthquake, climate, air quality, weather forecast and groundwater models. courses.subject: EASC
courses.title: Remote Sensing – Principles and Applications
courses.description: Remote sensing observations are critical for monitoring regional and global changes, determining spatial and temporal variability of the Earth System, and addressing fundamental global issues. This course introduces the basic physical principles of remote sensing, including electromagnetic waves and radiation, optical, microwave, and non-imaging remote sensing. It also presents key concepts and examples on remote sensing applications in Earth system science, such as the (atmosphere, lithosphere, hydrosphere, cryosphere), and global changes. This course also provides computer-based lab exercises that facilitate the understanding of remote sensing principles and the processing of remote sensing data.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Atmospheric Sciences
courses.learning_outcomes: This course will contribute to understanding of basic concepts and principles of remote sensing at optical and microwave frequencies from airborne and spaceborne platforms. With the help from laboratory analysis and case studies, remote sensing applications in Earth system science can be further understood. The students will develop: 1) the ability to evaluate an issue critically based on evidence and scientific principle, 2) to acquire knowledge effectively by self-study and using information technology, and to work independently, 3) to work effectively in a team, and 4) to present information in a clear, concise and logical manner. The students also can acquire a responsible attitude in study and work, and have motivation for life-long learning.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week Topics

1 Introduction, Remote sensing platforms

2 Electromagnetic waves and radiation, Electromagnetic interaction with matters

3 Radiative Transfer

4 Photogrammetry and stereogrammetry, Structure from Motion

5 Optical sensors

6 Remote Sensing Data Processing I: ENVI, color compositive, band math

7 Passive microwave remote sensing

8 Active remote sensing: Radar ranging

9 Active remote sensing: LiDAR ranging

10 Remote Sensing Data Processing II: data fitting

11 Synthetic Aperture Radar, Interferometric SAR

12 Remote Sensing Data Processing III: image processing, filtering

13 Remote Sensing Data Processing IV: change detection, classification

14 Machine learning and deep learning in remote sensing
courses.feedback_evaluation:
• Course evaluation: Tailored questionnaire to be answered by all students at the end of the course.
• Discussion with students – views and suggestions will be gathered regularly from students during tutorials.
• Reflection of teacher
courses.required_readings:
Emery W. and Camps A., Introduction to Satellite Remote Sensing, 1st edition. Elsevier, 2017.
Physical principles of remote sensing, 3rd edition, W.G. Rees, Cambridge University Press, 2013.
courses.recommended_readings:
Sabins, F., Remote Sensing: Principles and Interpretation, 3rd edition, Waveland Pr Inc;, 2007.
Mather, Paul M., Computer processing of Remotely-Sensed Images, Wiley, 2011.

courses.subject: EASC
courses.title: Practical Atmospheric Modeling
courses.description: This course introduces the basic principles of atmospheric modeling and provides hands-on practice to perform numerical simulations on University computing cluster. It begins with the concept of model and reviewing of physical and chemical processes in the atmosphere. After that, this course will cover introduction and hands-on practice of the three basic processes in atmospheric simulation: pre-processing data, modeling, and post-processing data. The pre-processing process refers to the preparation of data from various sources by different techniques such as the generation of emission inventories for atmospheric chemistry modeling. It then introduces numerical modeling basics such as “model equations and numerical approaches”. For post-processing, this course offers different skills in visualization of the model output and evaluation of model output against real-world observations. This course also introduces advanced knowledge in “model coupling” and “inverse modeling”. Finally, this course provides hands-on practice on simple model development experiments. During the course, we will cover basic Linux environment commands to perform the main tasks mentioned above. Overall, students can anticipate grasping basic modeling concepts and skills from this course, which are of great value to their future careers in both academia and industry.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Atmospheric Sciences
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Remember and explain the major chemical and physical processes that affect spatiotemporal variations of major atmospheric composition.
2. Explain the basic framework of atmospheric chemistry models including their input and output.
3. Understand what an emission inventory is and be able to pre-process emission inventory for atmospheric chemistry models.
4. Able to compile and run an atmospheric chemistry model.
5. Capable of visualizing model outputs and evaluating model outputs against observations.
6. Have the skills to sort out model structure by reading model codes and then revise model codes according to research needs.
courses.course_syllabus:
* The concept of model
* Processes in the atmosphere I - physical processes
* Processes in the atmosphere II - chemical processes
* Surface fluxes I - emission
* Surface fluxes II - deposition
* Model equations and numerical approaches
* Formulations of radiative, chemical, and aerosol rates
* Parameterization of subgrid-scale processes
* Post-processing model output data
* Model evaluation
* Model coupling
* Inverse modeling
* Model development experiments
courses.feedback_evaluation:
* Course evaluation: Tailored questionnaire to be answered by all students at the end of the course.
* Discussion with students – views and suggestions will be gathered at least two times during the term.
* Reflection of teacher.
courses.required_readings:
* Guy P. Grasseur and Daniel J. Jacob: Modeling of Atmospheric Chemistry, Cambridge University Press, 2017.

Please choose either “documents of the GEOS-Chem model” or “documents of the WRF model” as detailed below -

* Documents of the GEOS-Chem model
+ <https://geoschem.github.io/>
+ https://geos-chem.readthedocs.io/en/latest/

* Documents of the Weather Research & Forecasting Model (WRF) model.
+ https://www.mmm.ucar.edu/models/wrf -
+ https://www2.mmm.ucar.edu/wrf/users/docs/user\_guide\_v4/v4.4/contents.html
courses.recommended_readings:
* Scientific publications using the GEOS-Chem or WRF model.
* John H. Seinfeld and Spyros N. Pandis: Atmospheric Chemistry and Physics: From Air Pollution to Climate Change, John Wiley & Sons, 2016.
* Daniel J. Jacob: Introduction to Atmospheric Chemistry, Princeton University press, 1999.
